summary: despite years of planning and billions of dollars spent on disaster preparedness, the science of preparedness is in its infancy. as a result, it is challenging to define what it means to be “fully prepared” the world has dealt with numerous disasters, but only a handful of nations have confronted many. ness measures for various kinds of disasters include mass casualty, toxicologic, and biological events. this finding allows for improvements and greater efficiencies in planning and time-consuming and expensive drills and exercises. authors found that SOPs, training and drills made more of a contribution to overall preparedness than equipment and preparedness knowledge of personnel. a set of validated preparedness measures would support the dual goals of accountability and improved outcomes. authors declare that they have no competing interests. authors declare that they have no competing interests.
